questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a first unprovoked generalized tonic-clonic seizure. His physical exam and blood work are normal. MRI shows a focal cortical dysplasia. EEG shows epileptiform discharges over the left temporal region. Which of the following is the strongest predictor of seizure recurrence in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Age at onset

options.label: B
options.text: Normal neurological exam

options.label: C
options.text: Focal abnormality on neuroimaging

options.label: D
options.text: Absence of family history of epilepsy

questions.correct_answer: C. Focal abnormality on neuroimaging

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman reports experiencing a brief sensation of a rising epigastric discomfort followed by fear just before losing awareness. These episodes last less than a minute and are followed by confusion. Which of the following best describes the type of aura she is experiencing?

options.label: A
options.text: Auditory aura

options.label: B
options.text: Autonomic aura

options.label: C
options.text: Visual aura

options.label: D
options.text: Somatosensory aura

questions.correct_answer: B. Autonomic aura

questions.text: A 7-year-old child has multiple daily episodes of sudden unresponsiveness lasting 10–15 seconds, often mistaken for daydreaming. There is no aura or post-ictal confusion. EEG shows 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges. What is the most specific clinical feature suggesting absence seizure?

options.label: A
options.text: Presence of automatisms

options.label: B
options.text: Eye deviation during the event

options.label: C
options.text: Todd's paresis following episodes

options.label: D
options.text: Abrupt onset and offset of impaired awareness

questions.correct_answer: D. Abrupt onset and offset of impaired awareness

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding epilepsy management in pregnancy is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: Valproate is preferred in pregnancy due to superior seizure control and minimal teratogenicity

options.label: B
options.text: Lamotrigine clearance increases during pregnancy, often requiring dose adjustments

options.label: C
options.text: The risk of neural tube defects is highest with antiepileptic exposure during the first trimester

options.label: D
options.text: Generalized tonic-clonic seizures pose greater fetal risk than focal aware seizures

questions.correct_answer: A. Valproate is preferred in pregnancy due to superior seizure control and minimal teratogenicity

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the diagnosis or management of status epilepticus is CORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: A generalized tonic-clonic seizure lasting 4 minutes meets the diagnostic criteria for status epilepticus

options.label: B
options.text: Lorazepam is avoided in elderly patients with status epilepticus due to risk of respiratory depression

options.label: C
options.text: Failure to respond to benzodiazepines and levetiracetam defines super-refractory status epilepticus

options.label: D
options.text: Non-convulsive status epilepticus may persist following resolution of convulsive activity and requires EEG monitoring

questions.correct_answer: D. Non-convulsive status epilepticus may persist following resolution of convulsive activity and requires EEG monitoring

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding pre-hospital (first aid) management of an active seizure is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: Placing the patient in the lateral position after convulsions helps maintain airway patency and reduces aspiration risk

options.label: B
options.text: Attempting to open the mouth forcibly during the seizure can help prevent tongue laceration

options.label: C
options.text: Prolonged convulsions lasting more than 5 minutes warrant immediate emergency medical services activation

options.label: D
options.text: Loosening tight clothing around the neck can help reduce the risk of airway compromise

questions.correct_answer: B. Attempting to open the mouth forcibly during the seizure can help prevent tongue laceration

questions.text: Which of the following features is more suggestive of a seizure rather than syncope?

options.label: A
options.text: Preceding lightheadedness and visual dimming

options.label: B
options.text: Tongue biting on the lateral aspect

options.label: C
options.text: Immediate recovery without confusion

options.label: D
options.text: Provocation by prolonged standing or emotional distress

questions.correct_answer: B. Tongue biting on the lateral aspect

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with a slowly progressive hand tremor that worsens when he is reaching for objects but is absent at rest. Neurological exam reveals no rigidity or bradykinesia. Which of the following is the most likely type of tremor?

options.label: A
options.text: Rest tremor

options.label: B
options.text: Intention tremor

options.label: C
options.text: Essential tremor

options.label: D
options.text: Physiological tremor

questions.correct_answer: B. Intention tremor

questions.text: Which of the following movement disorders is characterized by sustained or intermittent muscle contractions causing twisting, repetitive movements or abnormal postures, often exacerbated by voluntary action?

options.label: A
options.text: Dystonia

options.label: B
options.text: Chorea

options.label: C
options.text: Myoclonus

options.label: D
options.text: Tics

questions.correct_answer: A. Dystonia

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding gait abnormalities in neurological disorders is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: Parkinsonian gait is characterized by reduced arm swing, shuffling steps, and festination

options.label: B
options.text: Sensory ataxic gait improves with visual input and worsens in the dark

options.label: C
options.text: Spastic hemiparetic gait is commonly seen after stroke and features circumduction of the leg

options.label: D
options.text: Cerebellar ataxic gait typically improves when the patient walks with feet closer together and eyes open

questions.correct_answer: D. Cerebellar ataxic gait typically improves when the patient walks with feet closer together and eyes open

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the clinical features of Parkinsonism is CORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: Rest tremor in Parkinsonism typically improves with voluntary movement and worsens at rest

options.label: B
options.text: Postural instability is an early feature and usually precedes bradykinesia

options.label: C
options.text: Parkinsonian rigidity is velocity-dependent and commonly described as “clasp-knife” in nature

options.label: D
options.text: Bradykinesia refers solely to slowed walking speed

questions.correct_answer: A. Rest tremor in Parkinsonism typically improves with voluntary movement and worsens at rest

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the etiologies of Parkinsonism is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: Wilson’s disease can present as juvenile-onset parkinsonism with additional hepatic or psychiatric features

options.label: B
options.text: Long-term levodopa therapy can lead to Parkinsonism due to dopaminergic neuronal exhaustion

options.label: C
options.text: Chronic carbon monoxide exposure causes Parkinsonism by targeting the globus pallidus and substantia nigra

options.label: D
options.text: Drug-induced Parkinsonism typically presents bilaterally and is less likely to cause resting tremor than idiopathic Parkinson’s disease

questions.correct_answer: B. Long-term levodopa therapy can lead to Parkinsonism due to dopaminergic neuronal exhaustion

questions.text: Which of the following features is most characteristic of Dementia with Lewy Bodies (DLB) and helps differentiate it from other dementias?

options.label: A
options.text: Progressive memory loss with early hippocampal atrophy

options.label: B
options.text: Gradual onset of personality changes and disinhibition

options.label: C
options.text: Fluctuating cognition with recurrent visual hallucinations

options.label: D
options.text: Stepwise cognitive decline associated with focal neurological deficits

questions.correct_answer: C. Fluctuating cognition with recurrent visual hallucinations

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS) in Parkinson’s disease is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: DBS is most effective in patients with good levodopa responsiveness but severe motor fluctuations

options.label: B
options.text: The ventral posterolateral nucleus of the thalamus is the preferred DBS target in Parkinson’s disease

options.label: C
options.text: Common DBS targets include the subthalamic nucleus and the globus pallidus internus

options.label: D
options.text: DBS may improve tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia, but has limited effect on non-motor symptoms

questions.correct_answer: B. The ventral posterolateral nucleus of the thalamus is the preferred DBS target in Parkinson’s disease

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with progressive right-sided weakness and increased muscle tone. On examination, there is spasticity, hyperreflexia, and an extensor plantar response on the right side. Which of the following best explains the clinical significance of the plantar response in this context?

options.label: A
options.text: It confirms a lesion localized to the lower motor neuron affecting the anterior horn cells

options.label: B
options.text: It reflects dysfunction of the corticospinal tract, typically above the spinal cord level of S1

options.label: C
options.text: It indicates a cerebellar lesion leading to loss of coordination and postural reflexes

options.label: D
options.text: It confirms damage to peripheral sensory afferents mediating the flexor withdrawal reflex

questions.correct_answer: B. It reflects dysfunction of the corticospinal tract, typically above the spinal cord level of S1

questions.text: Which of the following is correctly matched with its corresponding component and score in the ABCD2 score used for risk stratification after a transient ischemic attack (TIA)?

options.label: A
options.text: Blood pressure ≥140/90 mmHg – 1 point

options.label: B
options.text: Clinical feature of syncope – 2 points

options.label: C
options.text: Duration of symptoms <10 minutes – 2 points

options.label: D
options.text: Age ≥60 years – 1 point

questions.correct_answer: D. Age ≥60 years – 1 point

questions.text: A 65-year-old hypertensive man presents with sudden-onset hemiparesis involving the face, arm, and leg equally. He is conscious but has no aphasia, neglect, or sensory loss. Which of the following is the most likely anatomical site of the lesion?

options.label: A
options.text: Left precentral gyrus (motor cortex)

options.label: B
options.text: Left posterior limb of internal capsule

options.label: C
options.text: Left thalamus

options.label: D
options.text: Left corona radiata

questions.correct_answer: B. Left posterior limb of internal capsule

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman was involved in a car accident and suffered a severe whiplash injury but was otherwise well. The following day she presents to casualty with weakness on her right side, confusion and incomprehensible speech. On examination she has a left sided Horner’s syndrome, right hemiplegia and right homonymous hemianopia. Unfortunately, she became drowsy and obtunded over the next 24 hours and dies. Which of the following lesion best explains her disorder:

options.label: A
options.text: Total left middle cerebral artery infarction.

options.label: B
options.text: Lacunar infarction of internal capsule.

options.label: C
options.text: Cerebellar hemorrhage.

options.label: D
options.text: Internal carotid artery occlusion.

questions.correct_answer: D. Internal carotid artery occlusion.

questions.text: A patient with a right middle cerebral artery (MCA) stroke ignores stimuli on the left side and only eats food from the right half of the plate. Which of the following is most consistent with this deficit?

options.label: A
options.text: Left optic tract lesion

options.label: B
options.text: Left occipital lobe infarct

options.label: C
options.text: Right frontal eye field damage

options.label: D
options.text: Right inferior parietal lobule lesion

questions.correct_answer: D. Right inferior parietal lobule lesion

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding intravenous thrombolysis in acute ischemic stroke is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: Thrombolysis can be safely administered up to 12 hours from symptom onset in all patients

options.label: B
options.text: Non-contrast CT is mandatory to rule out hemorrhage before thrombolysis

options.label: C
options.text: The standard thrombolytic agent used is alteplase at a dose of 0.9 mg/kg (max 90 mg)

options.label: D
options.text: Thrombolysis is contraindicated in patients with active internal bleeding or recent intracranial surgery

questions.correct_answer: A. Thrombolysis can be safely administered up to 12 hours from symptom onset in all patients

questions.text: A 62-year-old right-handed man presents after a left MCA stroke. He speaks fluently but his sentences lack meaning, and he has poor comprehension and repetition. Which of the following best describes this type of aphasia?

options.label: A
options.text: Broca's aphasia

options.label: B
options.text: Conduction aphasia

options.label: C
options.text: Transcortical sensory aphasia

options.label: D
options.text: Wernicke's aphasia

questions.correct_answer: D. Wernicke's aphasia

questions.text: Which of the following statements about types of dysarthria is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: Spastic dysarthria is characterized by strained-strangled voice and slow, effortful speech due to bilateral upper motor neuron lesions

options.label: B
options.text: Ataxic dysarthria features irregular articulation, scanning speech, and is associated with cerebellar lesions

options.label: C
options.text: Hypokinetic dysarthria is commonly seen in Parkinson’s disease and presents with low volume, monotone, and rapid speech

options.label: D
options.text: Flaccid dysarthria results from upper motor neuron damage and typically shows hypernasality with preserved reflexes

questions.correct_answer: D. Flaccid dysarthria results from upper motor neuron damage and typically shows hypernasality with preserved reflexes

questions.text: Which of the following is a common delayed complication of aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage and is typically managed with nimodipine?

options.label: A
options.text: Obstructive hydrocephalus

options.label: B
options.text: Rebleeding within 24 hours

options.label: C
options.text: Cerebral vasospasm leading to delayed ischemia

options.label: D
options.text: Seizure occurring at the time of ictus

questions.correct_answer: C. Cerebral vasospasm leading to delayed ischemia

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Dejerine-Roussy syndrome is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a central post-stroke pain syndrome following a lesion of the thalamus

options.label: B
options.text: It typically results from infarction of the anterior cerebral artery territory

options.label: C
options.text: Patients may initially have hemisensory loss followed by delayed onset of pain and dysesthesia

options.label: D
options.text: The pain is often described as burning, lancinating, or electric-shock like

questions.correct_answer: B. It typically results from infarction of the anterior cerebral artery territory

questions.text: Which of the following findings is most characteristic of an ACA territory infarct?

options.label: A
options.text: Contralateral homonymous hemianopia

options.label: B
options.text: Fluent aphasia with impaired comprehension

options.label: C
options.text: Contralateral leg weakness greater than arm weakness

options.label: D
options.text: Hemiballismus due to subthalamic nucleus involvement

questions.correct_answer: C. Contralateral leg weakness greater than arm weakness

questions.text: Which of the following histopathological findings is characteristic of Alzheimer’s disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Lewy bodies in the substantia nigra

options.label: B
options.text: Pick bodies in the frontal and temporal cortex

options.label: C
options.text: Demyelination with perivascular lymphocytic infiltrates

options.label: D
options.text: Extracellular β-amyloid plaques and intracellular neurofibrillary tangles

questions.correct_answer: D. Extracellular β-amyloid plaques and intracellular neurofibrillary tangles

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Huntington’s disease is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: It is caused by a trinucleotide repeat expansion on chromosome 21

options.label: B
options.text: It involves degeneration of GABAergic neurons in the caudate nucleus

options.label: C
options.text: The disease typically presents with chorea, psychiatric symptoms, and cognitive decline

options.label: D
options.text: Anticipation is more severe when the mutation is inherited paternally

questions.correct_answer: A. It is caused by a trinucleotide repeat expansion on chromosome 21

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman notices her right pupil is much larger than the left while applying makeup. Which of the following conditions may be associated with a dilated (mydriatic) pupil?

options.label: A
options.text: A lesion in the midbrain

options.label: B
options.text: Horner’s syndrome

options.label: C
options.text: Terminally ill patients taking morphine for analgesia

options.label: D
options.text: A pontine lesion

questions.correct_answer: A. A lesion in the midbrain

questions.text: The following may cause a third nerve palsy:

options.label: A
options.text: Idiopathic intracranial hypertension

options.label: B
options.text: Multiple sclerosis

options.label: C
options.text: Herniation of the uncus of the temporal lobe

options.label: D
options.text: Pancoast tumor

questions.correct_answer: C. Herniation of the uncus of the temporal lobe

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with bilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation over the shoulders and upper arms, described as a "cape-like" distribution. Motor strength is preserved initially. Which of the following best explains the underlying pathophysiology?

options.label: A
options.text: Demyelination of dorsal columns in the cervical cord

options.label: B
options.text: Degeneration of corticospinal tracts in the thoracic cord

options.label: C
options.text: Compression of anterior spinal artery leading to infarction

options.label: D
options.text: Disruption of decussating spinothalamic fibers in the anterior white commissure

questions.correct_answer: D. Disruption of decussating spinothalamic fibers in the anterior white commissure

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most commonly associated with a positive Beevor's sign, characterized by upward movement of the umbilicus on attempting to sit up from a supine position?

options.label: A
options.text: Cervical spinal cord injury above C4

options.label: B
options.text: Facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy (FSHD)

options.label: C
options.text: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)

options.label: D
options.text: Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome

questions.correct_answer: B. Facioscapulohumeral muscular dystrophy (FSHD)

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with: • Right-sided weakness (arm + leg) • Right-sided loss of vibration and joint position sense • Left-sided loss of pinprick sensation What is the most appropriate investigation to secure the diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Nerve conduction study

options.label: B
options.text: Lumbar puncture

options.label: C
options.text: MRI of cervical spinal cord

options.label: D
options.text: MRI of the brain

questions.correct_answer: C. MRI of cervical spinal cord

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the Romberg test is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: A positive Romberg sign suggests impaired proprioception or sensory ataxia

options.label: B
options.text: The test is primarily used to assess cerebellar function

options.label: C
options.text: The test is performed by asking the patient to stand with feet together and eyes closed

options.label: D
options.text: Patients with vestibular or dorsal column dysfunction may sway or fall when the eyes are closed

questions.correct_answer: B. The test is primarily used to assess cerebellar function

questions.text: Which of the following features is more characteristic of conus medullaris syndrome than cauda equina syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Symmetric lower limb weakness and early bladder involvement

options.label: B
options.text: Asymmetric radicular pain radiating down the legs

options.label: C
options.text: Hyporeflexia with asymmetrical areflexic paralysis

options.label: D
options.text: Sensory loss in a dermatomal pattern with preserved perianal sensation

questions.correct_answer: A. Symmetric lower limb weakness and early bladder involvement

questions.text: Regarding the jaw-jerk reflex, which of the following statements is CORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: It is mediated by afferent fibers of the glossopharyngeal nerve

options.label: B
options.text: A brisk jaw-jerk is typical in peripheral trigeminal neuropathy

options.label: C
options.text: The motor limb is carried by the facial nerve’s marginal mandibular branch

options.label: D
options.text: A markedly exaggerated jaw-jerk suggests an upper motor-neuron lesion above the trigeminal motor nucleus

questions.correct_answer: D. A markedly exaggerated jaw-jerk suggests an upper motor-neuron lesion above the trigeminal motor nucleus

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with generalized myasthenia gravis tests positive for AChR antibodies. She is stable on pyridostigmine but has persistent fluctuating symptoms affecting daily activity. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Increase pyridostigmine to high-dose monotherapy

options.label: B
options.text: Start rituximab for rapid immunosuppression

options.label: C
options.text: Initiate corticosteroids for long-term immunomodulation

options.label: D
options.text: Perform urgent plasmapheresis to induce remission

questions.correct_answer: C. Initiate corticosteroids for long-term immunomodulation

questions.text: A 62-year-old chronic smoker presents with progressive difficulty rising from a chair and climbing stairs. Examination reveals proximal lower limb weakness, hyporeflexia, and mild dry mouth. After 10 seconds of sustained muscle contraction, his reflexes improve. Which of the following best supports the diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Proximal muscle weakness with reduced deep tendon reflexes that improve after exercise

options.label: B
options.text: Fluctuating fatigable weakness with preserved reflexes and positive anti-AChR antibodies

options.label: C
options.text: Cranial nerve involvement with early ptosis and diplopia, worse at end of day

options.label: D
options.text: Sudden-onset descending paralysis with pupillary involvement and preserved sensation

questions.correct_answer: A. Proximal muscle weakness with reduced deep tendon reflexes that improve after exercise

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with progressive limb weakness. Examination reveals spasticity in the lower limbs, wasting with fasciculations in the upper limbs, and brisk jaw jerk. He denies sensory symptoms or bowel/bladder dysfunction. Which of the following statements regarding ALS is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of both upper and lower motor neuron signs in different regions supports the diagnosis

options.label: B
options.text: A brisk jaw jerk suggests corticobulbar tract involvement

options.label: C
options.text: Early impairment of pin-prick and vibration sensation is typical in ALS

options.label: D
options.text: Riluzole may modestly prolong survival by inhibiting glutamatergic excitotoxicity

questions.correct_answer: C. Early impairment of pin-prick and vibration sensation is typical in ALS

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA) is CORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: It is caused by a mutation in the dystrophin gene on the X chromosome

options.label: B
options.text: It primarily affects the corticospinal tract and results in spasticity

options.label: C
options.text: It is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the SMN1 gene

options.label: D
options.text: Sensory loss and brisk reflexes are hallmark findings in classic SMA type 1

questions.correct_answer: C. It is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the SMN1 gene

questions.text: Which of the following is considered a red flag (danger sign) that warrants urgent evaluation in a patient presenting with headache?

options.label: A
options.text: Headache relieved by lying down and aggravated by stress

options.label: B
options.text: Bilateral throbbing headache with photophobia in a known migraine patient

options.label: C
options.text: Sudden-onset severe headache described as “the worst headache of life”

options.label: D
options.text: Headache triggered occasionally by missed meals and sleep deprivation

questions.correct_answer: C. Sudden-onset severe headache described as “the worst headache of life”

questions.text: A 28-year-old obese woman presents with daily pulsatile headaches, transient visual blurring on bending forward, and horizontal diplopia. Fundoscopy shows bilateral papilledema. MRI brain with MRV is unremarkable. Lumbar puncture reveals opening pressure of 320 mm H₂O with normal CSF composition. Which of the following statements is INCORRECT regarding this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Cranial nerve VI palsy may occur due to raised intracranial pressure

options.label: B
options.text: Therapeutic lumbar puncture can provide transient symptom relief

options.label: C
options.text: MRI may show empty sella or flattening of the posterior sclera

options.label: D
options.text: The diagnosis is supported by low CSF opening pressure with elevated protein

questions.correct_answer: D. The diagnosis is supported by low CSF opening pressure with elevated protein

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman reports recurrent episodes of visual zigzag lines followed by right-sided throbbing headache, photophobia, and nausea. Each episode lasts several hours and resolves spontaneously. Regarding migraine with aura, which of the following is TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: Aura symptoms typically begin after the headache has started

options.label: B
options.text: The aura evolves gradually over minutes and is fully reversible

options.label: C
options.text: Visual aura symptoms always indicate occipital lobe infarction on MRI

options.label: D
options.text: A duration of aura exceeding 60 minutes confirms migrainous infarction

questions.correct_answer: B. The aura evolves gradually over minutes and is fully reversible

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding cluster headache is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: It is more common in males and often occurs during sleep

options.label: B
options.text: Attacks are typically unilateral and associated with autonomic symptoms

options.label: C
options.text: Acute episodes are best treated with high-flow oxygen or subcutaneous sumatriptan

options.label: D
options.text: Chronic daily use of triptans is the mainstay of long-term prevention

questions.correct_answer: D. Chronic daily use of triptans is the mainstay of long-term prevention

questions.text: Which of the following cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) findings is most consistent with acute pyogenic meningitis?

options.label: A
options.text: Opening pressure <100 mm H₂O, clear fluid, normal glucose

options.label: B
options.text: Lymphocytic predominance, mildly elevated protein, normal glucose

options.label: C
options.text: Elevated pressure, xanthochromia, high RBC count

options.label: D
options.text: Elevated pressure, neutrophilic pleocytosis, low glucose, and high protein

questions.correct_answer: D. Elevated pressure, neutrophilic pleocytosis, low glucose, and high protein

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding tuberculous meningitis (TBM) is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: Basal exudates seen on imaging are a classic feature of TBM

options.label: B
options.text: CSF findings typically show neutrophilic predominance with normal glucose

options.label: C
options.text: Hydrocephalus is a common complication of TBM

options.label: D
options.text: Anti-tubercular therapy must be initiated promptly, often before culture confirmation

questions.correct_answer: B. CSF findings typically show neutrophilic predominance with normal glucose

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS) on monthly natalizumab infusions develops progressive left arm weakness and numbness over 3 weeks. What is the next best step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Inform patient that he has entered progressive course

options.label: B
options.text: MRI brain with contrast and lumbar puncture

options.label: C
options.text: Prescribe steroids then give next natalizumab infusion

options.label: D
options.text: Switch to an alternative drug due to failure of natalizumab

questions.correct_answer: B. MRI brain with contrast and lumbar puncture

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding neurocysticercosis (NCC) is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: Albendazole is contraindicated in all forms of NCC, including single parenchymal lesions

options.label: B
options.text: Seizure is the most common clinical presentation of parenchymal NCC

options.label: C
options.text: MRI may show the “hole-with-dot” sign representing scolex

options.label: D
options.text: Perilesional edema and enhancement are typical of the colloidal vesicular stage

questions.correct_answer: A. Albendazole is contraindicated in all forms of NCC, including single parenchymal lesions

questions.text: Which of the following features best helps distinguish medial medullary syndrome from lateral medullary syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Dysphagia and hoarseness due to nucleus ambiguus involvement

options.label: B
options.text: Ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome due to sympathetic tract involvement

options.label: C
options.text: Contralateral hemiparesis with ipsilateral tongue deviation

options.label: D
options.text: Vertigo and ataxia due to inferior cerebellar peduncle involvement

questions.correct_answer: C. Contralateral hemiparesis with ipsilateral tongue deviation

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is INCORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: Oligoclonal bands in CSF are a supportive diagnostic marker

options.label: B
options.text: Internuclear ophthalmoplegia is a classic brainstem finding in MS

options.label: C
options.text: Demyelinating plaques are commonly seen in periventricular and juxtacortical regions

options.label: D
options.text: A normal MRI brain rules out MS in all suspected cases

questions.correct_answer: D. A normal MRI brain rules out MS in all suspected cases

questions.text: Which of the following features is most characteristic of Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder (NMOSD)?

options.label: A
options.text: MRI brain typically shows Dawson’s fingers and periventricular lesions

options.label: B
options.text: Anti-MOG antibodies are positive in the majority of classic NMO cases

options.label: C
options.text: Spinal cord lesions in NMO are usually short and peripherally located

options.label: D
options.text: Longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis involving ≥3 vertebral segments is typical

questions.correct_answer: D. Longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis involving ≥3 vertebral segments is typical
